body: I believe I have addressed all issues found in the review now.
Test has been added and another similar potential issue was discovered by the test and fixed

I noticed some missing Runner.reset calls and added them where necessary, which ended up affecting a number of additional files.  If these changes pass all checks and look OK, I'll squash the commits together so someone can merge the pull request.
Updates look good to me. +1 to squash and merge
Commits squashed, checks pass, ready for merge.
All fixed now except for runtime expressions.  Please see `TestDelimiterProperties.test_emptyInitiator4 ` for the test and help.

Strangely enough, IDEA debugger wouldn't break at beginning of DelimiterTextParser#parse but did break at line 99, so was able to complete fix.  Runtime expressions are checked now too.  Please review and I will squash back to one commit once I get two approvals.

Another question.  I realized that "lazy val" and "def" are both lazy-evaluating and "def" is more lightweight (it doesn't need space for a member field) and just as fast if called only once or twice.  I've noticed some objects in the IDEA debugger seem to have a lot of member fields, which is good for inspecting but possibly a drag on performance.  Why does InitiatedTerminatedMixin use "lazy val" instead of "def" for everything InitiatedTerminatedMixin defines?

Many of the idioms we're using in Daffodil (in the schema compiler part anyway) are functional programming based. Lazy evaluation with value capture is essential to get linear behavior. Changing lazy vals to def can cause an exponential growth in computation simply recomputing the same thing multiple times (when that recomputation is happening in a recursive nest). So the rule of thumb is use def for abstract methods or methods with arguments or constants. Use lazy val everywhere else, and nothing can use side-effect or order-of-evaluation dependent computations. This of course applies to the schema compiler. Once we get to the runtime engine, imperative java-style code is the rule, and lazy evaluation and functional programming idoms like map/reduce/fold/loop-comprehensions are pretty much not used at all.

> Strangely enough, IDEA debugger wouldn't break ....

I've generally found Scala debuggers to be finicky. IDEA is a notch better than Eclipse for scala debug. But break on class construction sometimes fails, particularly for something like on construction of a NullPointerException, which would be really nice, but it doesn't work. The basics do work to a useful degree.
Fixups done.  Very useful to know that lazy val is more performative in schema compiler because of nested recursive calls.
Commits are squashed and ready to be merged now.

Once we incorporate this fix, are there compiler options that we can put into build.sbt to insure we don't end up adding the obsolete construct back again?

I'd like at least a warning if we add this syntax back.

It looks like this syntax is deprecated by default starting in 2.13., however for pre 2.13 we would have to use the `-Xfuture` flag (which was noted in jira).

I just tested with `-Xfuture` locally in both this PR branch and master and get expected behavior
- compile fails in master
- compile succeeds in PR branch
- compile fails in PR branch if procedure syntax is used

Will add that option in another commit on this PR.

Offhand I am not sure what else -Xfuture could impact...

Based on https://github.com/scala/scala/pull/3076/, it looks like the ``-Xfuture`` scalacOption enables a check for this. Not sure what other checks this flag enables, but it would probably be a good goal to enable that flag and fix whatever issues show up.

Based on this change https://github.com/scala/scala/pull/6325, it looks like scala 2.13 (which we don't support yet) changes it to the ``-Xsource:2.14`` flag. Scala 2.13 has been out for about a year, so it might be worth considering upgrading to that as well at some point.
Looking into the failures.  It appears Scalafix skipped rewriting tests, causing failed compilation when running tests + Xfuture.

That looks better, had to qualify test to have scalafix rewrite them

`sbt test:"scalafix ProcedureSyntax"`

That added a lot of changes, moving the total (5194) more inline with what was noted in jira (3476).

Tests pass locally with Xfuture, still getting CI failures though.  Thoughts?
Eh, I see it skipped some integration tests too....

It might have been easier for this task, given the complex layout of this project, to just specify the root directory rather than trying to use sbt project mappings

`sbt "scalafix ProcedureSyntax -f /home/path/to/incubator-daffodil"`
Ah, yeah will need separate options for 2.11...

Looks good to me.

I followed the [scala/bug#11467](https://github.com/scala/bug/issues/11467) link, wondered who sjrd was, googled, found out he authored Scala.js, browsed his Twitter page, and learned about some interesting stuff including [scalafix-organize-imports](https://github.com/liancheng/scalafix-organize-imports).  Seems even more powerful than scalafix's RemoveUnused rule since it organizes all imports nicely into groups, although only one or the other rule should be used.
It needs squashed some.  Do you want two commits with the build.sbt changes left separate, or squash it all into one?

I think one commit is fine in this case. It's maybe a little difficult for the important build.sbt change to stand out, but it is usually going to be the first file listed in a diff so it's not too hidden.

+1  Steve encouraged me to try out my committer bit :-).

Once your squashed commit passes the checks, I'll see if I can merge your commit too.

The daffodil-japi subproject is written in scala, but we want to generate javadocs for, since the intended usage is with Java code. There is a scala compiler plugin called [genjavadoc](https://github.com/lightbend/genjavadoc) that will generate javadocs from scala source files. You don't actually need to use the unidoc plugin to get this feature. The latest version of this scalac compiler plugin is 0.16.

The sbt-unidoc plugin essentially just takes java/scaladocs from subprojects and combines them into one big java/scaladoc. The 0.4.3 is the version of the sbt-unidoc plugin. Note that sbt-unidoc also acts as a wrapper around genjavadoc, so you gen generate javadocs for a subproject using the scala compiler plugin, and then sbt-unidoc will pull those in when it combines everything.

So in short, one version is for the sbt-unidoc plugin, the other is for the genjavadoc plugin that it wraps.

I originally did a visual inspection and things looked the same. To confirm, I just ran a diff to see what the actual changes were:
1. Javadoc includes a generation timestamp. I'm thinking it make sense to include the {{-notimestamp}} option when generating docs so we don't get a 1000 line diff of just timestamps.
2. The order of two rows in a deprecation table are randomly flipped. No idea why this happened, but it doesn't really matter I guess.
3. I modified the root-doc.txt file, which is apparently included in many scaladoc files as a tooltip. This diff is expected, but the tooltip should be something different instead of the entire contents of that file. I'll see if that's easy to fix.
4. The UDF API additions, which is also expected.

So all diffs are expected. I think it's worth ammending this PR to disable timestamps and fix the tooltip.
Github isn't updating this PR with new commits to the branch. I'm going to close and create a new PR and see if that works.

New PR since Github was not updating the original pull request for a fixup commit. See original pull request here for comments and merge approvals.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-daffodil/pull/397

I'm wondering if we should modify the LICENSE/NOTICE files to not include Daffodil version information in the jar so that we don't have to remember to update these locations. There really should just be one place where the version number should need to exist. Someting like
```
(org/apache/daffodil/util/UniquenessCache.class in lib/org.apache.daffodil.daffodil-lib-*.jar)
```
IANAL, but I feel like using a glob here is pretty unambiuous about what file is being referenced.

@andrewjc2000, with two +1's this is ready to merge. Can you please squash all of your changes into a single commit, update the commit message based on the squashed state of the code, and add the bug number to the end of the commit message? Then this will be good to merge. Thanks for the contribution!
Agreed, <VERSION> is much more clear. Will fix.

@tuxji 

Regarding formatting, [DAFFODIL-2133](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DAFFODIL-2133) discusses one option for using scalariform to check to make sure code is formatted properly, and I think it can also make the changes. We could enable this check on GithubActions and cause a failure if it finds code that doesn't meet the guidelines. That way people submitting pull requests will see the issues and hopefully fix them before things get to review. It does mean we need to fix the entire code base to be consistent, which might be a big task.

Also, a minor comment about commit subjects. It's not necessary to include the bug number in the subject since it's included at the bottom of the commit message. Instead, a subject that explains what the commit actually changes is more useful. For example, "Validate XML boolean strings to values of either 0/false and 1/true". If we need more information about what led to this change, we can always look at the bug referenced in the commit message.  Rarely is the bug subject a meaningful commit subject.
Thanks for the review. All good comments! Updates made it fixup commit.

Right, so I can see that master contains SDE.scala with windows line endings. That seems to be the root of the problem. So I'm starting to wonder if we need a commit to fix that first? Or do we push this? Sorry its such a pain, but I've been elected to be the windows (always small w) guy.

So, to be clear. What I believe is happening. Master SDE.scala has windows CRLF. I created a branch off of Master. I have git configured to commit CRLF->LF. Thus the git diff.

It could be that we need a "clean" process. Hard to imagine this is the only case.

SDE.scala in master has LF line endings for me, and git on linux doesn't do any munging of line endings linke winows can, which confuses things. And I've checked out your PR branch, and then SDE.scala has CRLF line endings. So it definitely seems to me that this PR is changing from LF to CRLF, which we don't want.

Ususally git on windows has the ``core.autocrlf`` configuration option set to ``true``. This makes it so that when you checkout a branch, git wil convet the line endings to CRLF (which probably explains why it looks like a CRLF to you). And then when you make a commit, git will change them back to LF. So this all happens transparently to the user. But for some reason, it seems like git isn't converting the the CRLF back to a LF for this file. I have no idea why it wouldn't do that. All your other PR's have been fine. Maybe something is weird about this one file?

Note that it's also not a bad thing that you're using windows. It's great to have a diversity of build environments so tha we are more likely to catch environment specific issues. And it'll be good if we can figure out this issue so that we know how to fix if if more windows developers join the project and hit this problem.

Very interesting. I need to go deeper into this. I down loaded the zip of the repo to by pass git, and see that SDE.scala does not contain 0D. So git is having fun with me. Weird that its just this file. Stay tuned. And thanks.

Rick, I use a Windows 10 (winver 1909) laptop too.  I made git checkouts using Cygwin git for a long time using the following snippet inside my `~/.gitconfig`:

```ini
[core]
        safecrlf = true
        autocrlf = input
```

However, I now develop in Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) almost exclusively since the WSL experience (including Microsoft Terminal) has improved to the point where I feel like I'm using both Ubuntu 20.04 (inside Microsoft Terminal except for Emacs and IntelliJ IDEA which are running in their own windows using the VcXsrv X server) and Windows 10 at the same time.  The only concession I've made for Windows in my Ubuntu 20.04 environment's `~/.gitconfig` is to tell git to ignore files' executable bit in case a Windows program has created a file in my git checkout or my checkout is in a Windows filesystem instead of an Ubuntu filesystem:

```ini
[core]
        filemode = false
```

You may want to try WSL too which will allow you to mix and match your favorite development tools as you wish.  For example, I also run Visual Studio Code natively on Windows with a plugin that performs remote compilations and debugging inside WSL.

Should all be correct now. Please let me know if you still see issues. It turned out to be a combination of config setting in git vs Intellij. I now have get configured with git config --global core.autocrlf false to do no conversion. And Intellij configured to use only LF, at the project level. That should do it. But, I will certainly keep an eye on it. All documented in the New Developer doc.
Looks like the linux integration tests failed because ubuntu does not have sh in ``/usr/bin/sh``, but only in ``/bin/sh``. Perhaps we should be using ``#!/usr/bin/env sh`` instead.

Please squash the commits into a single commit, force push, and we can merge this.

With your idea of just grepping, I looked for a places in the codebase that for ``\.format(`` or ``Any\*`` and did my best to verify that all places are now doing the right thing. Based on visual inspection, I think this was the only case where we weren't handling varargs correctly, or where we were incorretly passing a Seq to format call where we intended to expand the sequence.

It's definitely not a perfect check, and it wouldn't surprise me if there are some potential placeses missed due to other things that we should grep for, but as far as I can tell this was the only incorrect usage.

Merging this even though the scala 2.11 build on windows didn't pass its check.

This XSD for DFDL is used by Daffodil when it takes in a schema, to validate that it does not use any of the XSD features that are not in the DFDL subset of XSD. 

This was done by just commenting out specific lines of the original schema which is the w3c's XML Schema for XML Schema. 
That is, we didn't write this schema ultimately, we just adapted it. 

XML Schema is itself an XML-embedded language (for better or worse), so it's possible to write an XML Schema for it, but that's a meta-circular exercise that was tripping up XML validation in IDEs working with DFDL schemas. 

There is no-doubt other "dead code" in this schema. I think the goal is to continue to be able to diff this XML Schema for DFDL against the XML Schema for XML Schema so that if XML Schema evolves, we can identify and isolate the differences.

I think this schema does not enforce everything about the subset.
Let's close this pull request since we have opened a new pull request to replace it: <https://github.com/apache/incubator-daffodil/pull/422>.

Oops, I think I accidentally closed this pull request? I deleted the ``wip-daffodil-2202-runtime2`` since it had no commits, thinking it was just accidentally pushed to the asf repo instead of someones fork. But perhaps this PR was intentionally create to merge into this new branch rather than master?

Yes, I'd created the `wip-daffodil-2202-runtime2` branch in order to intentionally merge my PR into that branch rather than the main branch.  I haven't received a response from the os-lib author to the issue I opened (https://github.com/lihaoyi/os-lib/issues/47) and the absence of a Scala 2.11 os-lib build is preventing my PR from passing 6 of the 12 compile checks and Mike suggested using an integration branch so we don't mess up anyone else's PR.  Do you want me to use an integration branch or have me ask the devs list if it is time for Daffodil to drop support for Scala 2.11 yet?

Ah, that's my fault. Perhaps recreating the branch will reopn the pull request? Feel free to push that branch again, I'm not sure which commit it was on. Though, I'm not sure we really need a new branch unless the plan is to merge it in a sort of experimental state. Is the goal here as a preliminary review which much more work to be done, or do you think it's ready to merge into a branch that has more visibiilty and allow more development, but maybe isn't ready to be merged into master yet?

As for dropping 2.11, that's probably something we should start a thread on the dev list for. I believe the only reason we maintained that was for Apache Spark, which until recently only supported 2.11. But the latest versions of Spark supports 2.12, so it should probably be fine to drop.

Hmm, I think maybe codecov had a hiccup? The codecov for this commit says it's "Waiting for CI to complete".

https://codecov.io/github/apache/incubator-daffodil/commit/2a217d7c9041b6da9f1730c18a0fdf9314253702

I'll force push a new commit to retrigger the checks and see if works that time.

Yes, there is much more work that needs to be done to generate C code for a bigger subset of DFDL types and schemas.  I would say enough work has been done on my fork and now it's time to get more eyes, discussion, and collaboration on the runtime2 backend by building out the rest of the C code generator in public instead of my fork.  However, I can't predict how much pushback I would get from Daffodil developers if their sbt build starts trying to compile C source files as well as Scala source files.  I think it makes more sense to let multiple developers collaborate and experiment with the runtime2 backend on a new branch until we reach broad agreement on how the runtime2 backend should look and how it should affect the main Daffodil build.  That's why I picked the name `wip-daffodil-2202-runtime2` for the new branch.

I suggest the branch we put this on not be named "wip-" prefix, because it's only a wip until it isn't, also daffodil on the branch name isn't needed. I suggest naming the branch runtime2-2202. The ticket number is still useful because if you lookup the ticket there are links and info there (or should be).
OK, the PR will now merge to branch `runtime2-2202` and the `wip-daffodil-2202-runtime` branch is gone.

So there's the comment I was expecting, but code cov edited the comment everytime one of our 12 checks passes, which resulted in a bunch of spam to the commits list. Since this is now part of the check, I think and the inline warnings now appear on the actual code, I don't think we need these comments. I'll update the config to disable comments again.
There are a number of calls to DFDLTestSuite still outstanding, but I wanted to get this much in front of others for a sanity-check, and to ensure it builds on all of our target systems.

The email volume was due to the CI workflow running 12 compilation checks with code coverage enabled in every check.  We just dropped support for Scala 2.11 so that's 6 compilation checks now.  We don't have many Java files (just API wrappers) and they rarely change.  If Scala provides uniform features and functionality no matter which underlying Java is being used (I don't know - does it?), do we really need separate compilation checks for Java 8, 9, and 11?  Then that would leave only Linux and Windows compilation checks (definitely worth keeping), and we could modify the CI workflow to enable code coverage in only Linux, not both Linux and Windows.

I'd prefer to keep at least some of different checks. We probably don't need all 8, 9, and 11, but I think we need at least 8 for long term support, and at least the latest version (which we're behind, 13 has been out for a while, and I think I heard there's some failure 13). And we definitely need windows vs linux, we've had a handful of bugs that only appear on one OS. So I think the minimum we need is 4 (windows + linux + 2 java version). I suspect we'll also want to enable scala 2.13 relatively soon, so that will get us back to two scala versions. So I think it's going to hard to avoid excessive comments.

I don't personally find the above codecov bot report comment all that helpful. As long as the patch checks pass that feels reasonable. If the check fails, it provides a link to the report for the details that's in the codecov report. That feels sufficient to me. And I think we will still get the inline comments (which don't acttually create emails I think), it's just the code cov report comment that is disabled.

Sure, let's leave the codecov bot report commented out, although we still can modify the CI workflow if we want only specific compilation checks to run codecov.  I would be surprised if the codecov reports differ for Java 8, 9, and 11 although I would expect small differences for Linux and Windows.  

Speaking of Java versions, I don't think we need to worry about non-LTS releases anyway.  Java now has a fast channel, every six months, and a slow channel, every three years.  Each third-year release is called an LTS release.  Java 8 is the previous LTS release, Java 11 is the current LTS release, and 17 will be the next LTS release.  Unless there's a reason to test non-LTS releases, I'd chuck out Java 9 and test only Java 8, 11, and then 17 when it comes out.

Yeah, we probably can drop 9. We should definitley keep 8 as a lot of production operating systems like RHEL are still on these older LTS versions of java. Though I'll leave that to separate discussion about what OS's and Java versions we should support with CI. I'll lmerge this as is so that pull request no longer fail due to the codecov/project check.

I did some regression testing on a bunch of schemas and found that this causes a few schemas to fail. Needs further investigation to figure out what's going on, but I'll hold off on merging this until I figure it out.

I found and fix one issue, I think it's an existing issue that we just never hit. I can't even figure out a way to hit it, and wasn't able to simplify schemas/data to get an easily reproducable test. However, many private schemas now test, and I think visually this code is confirmed to be wrong. See commit message in 6fe93c478d for a description of the issue.

Looks like there is still one more failure in a private schema to fix.

Squashed and rebased.
Thanks John

Found the last issue, it actually wasn't really related to suspensions, but related to how the order of suspensions getting evaluated could change how we deliver buffered DOS to the direct DOS. Again, I'm struggling to create a simple test for this, but I think the code is fairly clear.

The issue here was that when we call setFinished on a DOS we deliver all the following buffered DOS's that have been finished so that we can release finished buffers. However, when we deliver multiple buffers, we always use the same ``FormatInfo`` as the original direct DOS. But Buffered DOS can change bitOrder, so the FormatInfo (which is where we get bitOrder) needs to change depending on the DOS. The fix is to save the FormatInfo associated with a buffered DOS when it is finished, and then use that when that DOS delivers buffered content. This allows the FormatInfo to change while delivering buffered content as we deliver different DOS.

Have a few questions Ill comment on here.

Looking at more tests while in review.
I dont understand the CI rat check failures, no libs are modified in this PR

I'll review this later today, but the rat check makes sure that all files have correct licenses. If new files are added without a license header, the rat check will fail. You can run ``sbt ratCheck`` and it will generate a report in ``target/rat.txt`` listing files that are missing a license header.

I think the files missing a license header in this PR are:
* daffodil-lib/src/main/resources/META-INF/services/org.apache.daffodil.api.Validator
* daffodil-lib/src/main/scala/org/apache/daffodil/api/Validator.scala
* daffodil-lib/src/main/scala/org/apache/daffodil/util/Validators.scala

Quick status update for everyone.  I paired with Mike on refactoring the CodeGenerator methods into a match/case expression and I completed these changes after our pairing session.  However, these changes introduced a code generation problem (one struct now has a member with a different name than it had before) which I haven't debugged yet since I've been spending all of my time on another project the last few days.  I have an all day meeting today, but tomorrow I'll debug that problem, commit the changes so far, and resume working on the rest of the requested changes.

@tuxji  yeah thanks, I had intended to do that.  Ill move it up there

Eh, no on second thought I didnt.  Will let it there for now unless someone feels strongly.

I'd like to also comment on the schematron validator.

I think we should fold it into Daffodil's source tree. I know you are trying to have an example of how to do it outside of daffodil, which is fine, but we need to be able to review that also. 

For example, it is printing things. It should be creating some sort of ValidationError instances, and adding them to validation errors somewhere, not printing.

> I'd like to also comment on the schematron validator.
> 
> I think we should fold it into Daffodil's source tree. I know you are trying to have an example of how to do it outside of daffodil, which is fine, but we need to be able to review that also.
> 
> For example, it is printing things. It should be creating some sort of ValidationError instances, and adding them to validation errors somewhere, not printing.

@mbeckerle I am fine with rolling it in if you want it.  IMO it would be better to get the SPI changes merged while working as close to possible as the way the validator was previously working, and then in additional PRs add schematron and add other nice to haves.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DAFFODIL-2409

Will add to commit message when squashed
I am ok with the plan to not fold schematron validation in to Daffodil as yet. I will look more at the xerces-based validator then.

Argument handling is getting out of control.  I implemented [some stuff](https://github.com/jw3/incubator-daffodil/blob/validator_spi/impl/daffodil-lib/src/main/scala/org/apache/daffodil/api/Validator.scala#L41-L55) today just to move the idea forward but didnt like doing it. 

The complexity around the argument handling is that we need to convert the CLI arguments entered as strings to the proper type, but only the validator implementation knows how to do that. The handling of these strings and the interface needed to support the CLI makes the API usage scary.
 
The code from today to try to bridge some of the gap was modeled after [typesafe config](https://github.com/lightbend/config).  And it hit me tonight we should just use that and it would offload a bunch of complexity and eliminate a bunch of code in this PR.  

Benefits are

- well known library
- allow us to accept configuration on cli or from file
- accept configuration in form of java props, json, or hocon
- can pull configuration from environment
- provides well known typed getters and setters
- unsurprising validation and error handling
- less of Daffodil to maintain
- Apache 2.0 licensed

Unless there are objections to using it, Im going to work it into the next iteration while responding to the latest feedback.

Something like that seems reasonable as far as configuration goes.

I still have concerns that even with something like typesafe config, we're still limiting Validation configuration to what can be represented by some configuration language (e.g. typesafe) just so that we can get plugability. I can imagine Validators that really can only be configured with code, granted I'm not sure if anything like that exists in the real world. And I don't personally feel that plugability gains much outside of CLI support.

But I won't block this change if others are fine with it.

I took a look at [typesafe config](https://github.com/lightbend/config) and I noticed the README listed some Scala wrapper libraries.  I was interested so I looked at these as well but most of them haven't been maintained in a while with the exception of [pureconfig](https://github.com/pureconfig/pureconfig).  It might be worth taking a look at pureconfig (it seems very well documented, which is a good sign for maintainability), but you might be better off using config if 1) pureconfig adds more code overhead than it's worth for features you don't want to use, or 2) people think its license (Mozilla Public License 2.0) might not be compatible enough with Apache License 2.0.

One thing to consider re: pureconfig is that we probably want to be able to support Validators written in Java. Sometimes libraries writen in scala can be difficult to use in Java code. I'm not familiat enough with pureconfig to know one way or the other. This doesn't really matter if it's all abstracted away and Validators don't actually need to call pureconfig functions, but if they do, that's somethign to keep in mind.

>I still have concerns that even with something like typesafe config, we're still limiting Validation configuration to what can be represented by some configuration language (e.g. typesafe) just so that we can get plugability.

I take from this your concern is that you want to ensure validator instances can be built and passed programmatically, not only be based on a SPI based  name lookup and argument bundle. 

>I can imagine Validators that really can only be configured with code, granted I'm not sure if anything like that exists in the real world.

Like I said somewhere above, the arg handling has gotten out of hand.  I want to reduce that and make the API aspect more ergonomic while being compatible with passing things from the CLI.  The focus on CLI first instead of API first is what has skewed the initial approach.

>And I don't personally feel that plugability gains much outside of CLI support.

There are plenty of applications that use SPI to supplement API usage.  Probably more useful to show compelling examples in this PR than to debate this point though, so Ill work on that and evolve this over the next few days.

Im still confident the current impl can be tweaked to address the API side concerns.

All fair points and I do agree that there are benefits to plugability. I think maybe we just need to find the right balance between plugablity and configurability. Those feel to me like they sort of are at odds with each other. Finding a good happy medium I think is worth the effort, and I too am confident it's possible.
Added some CLI tests should add more coverage to Main.scala, including this new code. I hate seeing that little red :x:

Yeah, I think you're reading the codecov right. It was correct that parts of this diff weren't covered, but how it showed that, as you say, doesn't feel right. If I run the commands to generate a coverage report locally, it feels a little more correct, but still not quite right. I think the challenge is just that Scala doesn't a bunch of stuff behind the scense, and the coverge tools just can't make an accurate represetnation of what's going on.

But it was correct that we didn't have CLI tests for different infoset types, and so no actual coverage for some of these changes I just made, and I think it was worth adding just to make sure we don't have any regressions in the future. The way this infosetDataToInputterData and getInfosetInputter is sort of fragile since they retun/accept AnyRef, so it's important that they have a little coverage.

How about a test mode? A settable flag in pstate/ustate and a mutable list.

Instead of just nilling the refs to things being released when the flag is set you also push them onto the list. At end of a test run we inspect the list to insure the right things have been put on the list?

Seems like small effort for a big increase in testability maintainability of this feature. Could be done for both parse and unparse.

In daffodil-core/src/test/scala/org/apache/daffodil/infoset/TestInfoset.scala<https://github.com/apache/incubator-daffodil/pull/437#discussion_r506448616>:

>     */
   def testInfoset(testSchema: scala.xml.Elem, infosetAsXML: scala.xml.Elem): (DIElement, Root, DaffodilTunables) = {
-    val schemaCompiler = Compiler().withTunable("allowExternalPathExpressions", "true")
+    val schemaCompiler =
+      Compiler()
+        .withTunable("allowExternalPathExpressions", "true")
+        .withTunable("releaseUnneededInfoset", "false")


It's actually kindof hard to write a test to make sure everything is getting cleaned up appropriately. At the end of unparsing, the DIDocument should have a single child, the root element. If that root element isn't used in an expression it should get set to null. So at the end of a parse, the DIDocument child(0) should be null if not used in an expression. But that only tests that we were able to free the root element. It's possible things were broken so that no a single other element was freed and the only thing actually freed was the root element. And since the root elemen was freed, there's no way to know if any of it's children were freed--we no longer have any access to it or it's children.

Maybe the best way to ensure this is working correctly is to just develop tests that would fail with OutOfMemory errors if we weren't cleaning up infoset correctly. Those tests would likely be too large/take too long to keep in the Daffodil repo, but I believe @dfthompson<https://github.com/dfthompson> is working on some tests that live in Owl's internal test infrastructure. Once those are done, we might want to find a place where those can be made public so others can test them.

Doesn't seem totally unreasonable. I guess individual tests would then need to manually maintain a list of elements that are expected to be freed and compare against this built-in list? I can't think of a good way to automate it the process.

The infoset "chunks" on the list of released ones might still convert to xml elements via toXML. If so you can take the whole array, convert to an XML doc by wrapping an element around them all, and a test can then contain a corresponding expected XML chunk to compare to it.

Not a bad idea, but I guess it still requires someone to manually create the expected XML. I was hoping for some other way things to just know what shoudl be release. But that's probably too difficult and fragile. I'll come up with a way to easy create the expected results. XML might be a good approach.

Another thought, what if instead we make it so that if we would have freed a DINode but didn't then we modify some new state in the DNIode that says that it would have been freed. And when we output the infoset as XML we have to ability to configure it to include an attribute saying it would have been freed. Then we just have these tests disable freeing output as XML with this attribute, and then we can easily inspect the XML to determine which elements would have been freed. No concerns with elemetn children being null, and the resulting XML should look exactly like the infoset, just with extra attributes. Thoughts?

That seems like a better choice. We just mark the nodes and convert to an XML attribute.

I'm still a little concerned this error message could be confusing. "selecting the first branch for unparsing" could be interpreted as it's always going to unparse the first branch of a choice, regardless of anything else. Which isn't the case. It's going to unparse the first branch with no elements, and it's only going to do that if the infoset does not identify which branch to unparse.
